table-wrap-foot.p: 1measures the quantity of interest and always returns the same output from the same input (e.g., given mass of produce).
2measures a parameter by giving a uniformly good estimate of the quantity of interest under certain conditions.

sec.title: What level of accuracy is required for each task/crop?
sec.p: Previous sections have illustrated the wide variety of yield sensing principles available for horticultural crops. These tend to generate data at different spatial resolutions that are determined by the type of yield sensor used and the mode of harvesting. For mechanical harvesting, most horticultural crops are at an advantage to broad-acre crops as harvesting is typically done on a single tree (stand-alone tree orchards) or on narrow transects (2-4 m) associated with either a single row (e.g., vineyards or trellised fruit systems) or only a few rows (potatoes, market vegetables, etc.) of crop. In mechanically harvested crops, there is usually little convolution or mixing within the harvester, i.e., the crop passes quickly from the plant, across the sensor to the collection container or trailer. As such, the data from continuous yield sensors are typically associated with a point in the field. For non-continuous systems (e.g., the automatic weighing of bins in an orchard in Whitney et al., 1999) or for the weighing of hand-harvested fruits, the spatial footprint may cover several individual trees or plants and will be an area measurement. In either case, the footprint of the yield data is usually small and/or well-defined, such that the geolocation of the data is more dependent on the accuracy of the GNSS receiver used, than on yield monitor effects. This contrasts, for example, with cereal crops that often use large (e.g., 10 m) cutter bars and have long lag times for the grain to move through the harvester. It is expected that a high accuracy GNSS receiver associated to a high quality and well-calibrated sensor will give precise and accurate yield data. These data may therefore appear very noisy as the short-term stochastic variance in the production system may be captured in the data.

The required accuracy of the data will be dependent on the end objectives. Several advantages of generating crop yield maps have been listed in the introduction. For practical purposes, these different uses of a yield map can be broken down into three main categories: (1) understanding spatial variability, (2) auditing production and (3) steering decisions for site-specific management.

For understanding general spatial patterns in yield response, yield monitors do not need to be accurate or precise, provided some effective form of smoothing or interpolation is applied in the generation of the final maps, and areas of the field are only compared on a relative basis. For instance, Pelletier & Upadhyaya (1999) observed a 50% yield reduction between the 20% most productive and the 20% least productive areas of the field, thus providing an important insight to the grower solely based on relative observations. Low accuracy often becomes de facto the case in agriculture if yield monitoring systems are poorly calibrated or operated. The key assumption is that any error or bias is either constant or proportional to the yield response. The final data can only be used to identify trends, not exact values of yield. This can inform growers on macro-variability existing in their fields and raise questions about poorly drained areas, significant changes in soil texture or edge effects for instance (Grisso et al., 2005; Schumann, 2010).

Some producers use yield sensors to obtain in-field information to audit harvested tonnage against delivered tonnage. This information is typically associated with blocks or areas of a production system. In this case, accurate, but not necessarily precise, yield monitors are needed, i.e., an individual point measurement may not be accurate, but the summed total is accurate when averaged over a bin or a truckload. It is important to note that even the best yield sensors will still be subject to some error and yield sensors are not sufficient to correctly audit exact tonnages at the moment. However, they can identify significant deviations (e.g., > 5% difference) which may be associated with losses in transport or logistical operations (Taylor et al., 2016).

When the intent of the yield data is to quantify and validate the effect of management on production, then producers need yield data that is both precise and accurate. This requires high quality yield sensors, high accuracy georeferencing systems and conscientious sensor and machinery operation during the calibration and harvesting processes. Accuracy in yield data becomes important when using these maps on an actual basis as opposed to a relative basis. The literature based on grain crops suggests that trends must be aggregated on multiple years in order to provide reliable information to growers (Blackmore et al., 2003; Xiang et al., 2007). Accurate yield data helps in comparing yield maps from one year to another, which would otherwise need to be normalized and thus lose information. In addition, for crops harvested multiple times during the crop growing season (e.g., peppers, zucchini, etc.), accurate yield data become mandatory to generate a cumulative yield map. The use of yield maps by the majority of grain growers for their decision making remains a challenge of precision agriculture to date (Bramley & Ouzman, 2019) and, if suggested approaches to on-farm experimentation are to be widely adopted (e.g. Bullock et al., 2020; Marchant et al., 2019), then yield monitors must generate yield data at a quality that generates confidence in making very targeted crop-specific decisions (and not just an assessment of spatial trends).

sec.title: Current trends and future perspectives
sec.p: As highlighted by the multiple advantages of possessing a yield map in the introduction, the demand for reliable and cost-effective yield monitoring system for horticultural crops will continue to grow. Indeed, horticulture crop growers understand the benefits of the data revolution in agriculture for productivity and environmental stewardship. The consumer demand for clean food along with stricter government regulations will maintain pressure on growers for more efficient use of resources (i.e., soil, water, fertilizers, and pesticides), which will be linked to the adoption of precision agriculture for mechanized farms (Schneider, 2017; Zhao et al., 2018). Yield maps are key for the optimization of inputs because they provide a spatialized result of the operations, a feedback loop that is important for spatial optimization of input use (Basso & Antle, 2020).

Calibration of yield monitoring systems has been a challenge for grain crop yield sensing and will remain a challenge for horticultural crop yield sensing as well (Nielsen, 2020). One aspect that will be investigated and may become more attractive for yield monitoring technologies is autonomous calibration. A self-calibrating system would increase reliability of yield data and thus improve usability for decision making. Technologies for autonomous calibration have been studied for grain crop yield monitoring (Beck & Pickett, 2006; Morgan, 2020). Based on the experience learned from grain crop yield sensing, developers of yield sensing technologies for horticultural crops may consider including self-calibration by design in their systems.

Agricultural robots may disrupt the development of yield sensing technologies. Agricultural robots will bring a new perspective by being close to the crop and operating at a relatively slower speed than current farm machinery. This will enable the use of tailored machine vision systems capable of collecting meaningful crop data enabling yield forecasting, yield mapping and selective harvest planning (Lowenberg-DeBoer et al., 2020; Underwood et al., 2016).

Another aspect of yield monitoring that will likely gain traction is sensor fusion. The advantages of sensor fusion include: reduced uncertainty (same information from multiple sources), better accuracy and reliability (bring redundancy in the system), improved resolution (combination of multiple measurements), and reduced complexity (dedicated sensors rather than a very complex sensing approach). Using multiple sensors increases the variety of data that can advantageously feed artificial intelligence algorithms (Misra et al., 2020). The addition of signals often reduces the error by increasing redundancy. The combination of sensing technologies will also simplify yield quantification and qualification as opposed to the use of one sensing approach. Based on existing literature, one can envision a yield monitoring system combining load cells to measure the harvested grape weight on-the-go along with florescence sensors measuring grape quality at the same time (Baluja et al., 2012). As mentioned previously, sensor fusion also presents options for autonomous calibration across multiple sensors (Pereira et al., 2016).

Machine vision is gaining momentum and new applications will continue to emerge. Machine vision-based solutions have already been investigated for all categories of horticultural crops covered in this study (Table 1), which shows the potential and the interest for this approach. Machine vision is the only approach offering the potential for both quantification and qualification of crop yield (González-González et al., 2020). Because of the relative simplicity of sensor deployment (i.e., installing cameras) and advances in deep learning implementation and powerful computing, machine vision is the approach showing the most potential for yield sensing of horticultural crops. However, it remains an empirical approach and limited by occlusion issues (Schueller, 2021), thus its combination with deterministic approaches, such as load cells will probability be basis of the most robust approaches to come.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Yield sensing and the availability of yield map present several advantages and opportunities for horticultural crop growers, thus justifying the continued development of monitoring approaches to generate reliable yield maps. The advent of digital agriculture and precision agriculture, which relies on crop management, environment, and production data to optimize the use of resources is highly dependent on yield maps and reliable yield monitoring technologies will enable horticultural crop production to fully embrace this new paradigm. The few commercial yield sensing technologies that exist for horticultural crops tend to be based on the load cell principle measuring yield mass on conveyor belt on the harvester on-the-go. Direct yield measurement can also be done on a volumetric basis or by counting production units (i.e., single fruit, bags, bins or boxes). The other approaches tested in the literature involve indirect yield measurement, which can be done by capacitance, vehicle tracking, machine vision, radiometry, remote sensing or by using RFID for yield tracking. Yield monitoring approaches can be classified as deterministic (i.e., measuring the quantity of interest) or empirical (i.e., establishing correlation between the sensed parameter and the quantity of interest). The deterministic approaches have the advantage of showing more robustness and being simpler while empirical approaches require more complexity due to conversion and are more adaptable to different contexts. The choice of the right yield monitoring approach is linked to the different context of each crop and should consider multiple factors such as adaptability, reliability, precision, and accuracy. The great diversity of products and organizations in horticulture explains the high diversity of measurement principles observed in the literature. Given this diversity, there will not be one measurement technology suitable for horticulture, but a range of suitable technologies adapted to each context and each product. This context will continue to call for original projects and research questions in the future. In general, despite the numerous papers published on yield monitoring approaches for horticultural crops, several problems remain before commercialisation. For instance, capacitance and volumetric sensing have received little attention as well as the fusion of multiple approaches. Machine vision and sensor fusion appear as promising approaches for monitoring crop yield on-the-go. The digital agriculture revolution for horticultural crops remains contingent upon the development of reliable and ubiquitous yield monitoring systems.
